name: (2Z,3Z)-N,N'-Dihydroxybutane-2,3-diimine
Reason: The compound in question has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic structure is a carbon chain similar to butane, which has a melting point of around -140°C. However, the presence of two imine groups (C=NH) and two hydroxyl groups (OH) significantly modifies the melting properties. Each imine group can increase the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds and increase the rigidity of the molecule, we can estimate this increase to be approximately +100°C per imine group. Similarly, each hydroxyl group can also form hydrogen bonds, raising the melting point further. We can estimate the increase from each hydroxyl group to be around +50°C. Additionally, the Z double bond conformation might slightly lower the melting point compared to an E conformation due to less effective packing, but this effect is likely small, on the order of -5°C. Combining these effects: Base chain: -140°C, Imines: +200°C (2x +100°C), Hydroxyls: +100°C (2x +50°C), Z conformation: -5°C.

name: (2Z,3Z)-N,N'-Dihydroxybutane-2,3-diimine
Reason: The compound (2Z,3Z)-N,N'-Dihydroxybutane-2,3-diimine has several functional groups that will affect its melting point. The basic unit we can compare to is butane, which has a melting point of -138.3°C. First, the presence of the oxime groups (–C=N–OH) will significantly raise the melting point due to increased polarity, and the ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds. The contribution of each oxime group to the melting point can be estimated to be +120°C, as it not only introduces polarity but also provides specific sites for hydrogen bonding. The fact that there are two oxime groups means this effect is doubled. Additionally, the double bond (–C=C–) in the compound will have a minor effect on the melting point compared to the major effect of the oxime groups because double bonds provide some rigidity to the molecule but do not contribute as significantly to intermolecular forces as hydrogen bonds do. We can estimate the double bond contributes +5°C. The presence of two double bonds will double this effect.
Prediction: Butane at -138.3°C + (2x oxime group effect) 2x120°C + (2x double bond effect) 2x5°C = -138.3°C + 240°C + 10°C = 111.7°C
